Package mz

Class Cocktail

java.lang.Object
mz.SortComparable
mz.Selection
mz.Bubble
mz.Cocktail
All Implemented Interfaces:
SelectionInterface<Comparable>, Sort<Comparable>, SortFind<Comparable>, SortSwap<Comparable>
Direct Known Subclasses:
Comb, IntroCocktail
public class Cocktail extends Bubble
Cocktail Sort, also known as Cocktail Shaker Sort or Bidirectional Bubble Sort, is a variation of the Bubble Sort algorithm. It works by repeatedly moving through the list in both directions, comparing adjacent elements and swapping them if they are in the wrong order. This bidirectional movement helps to optimize the sorting process by sorting the largest and smallest elements simultaneously.
Since:
1.0

  • Constructor Details

    • Cocktail

      public Cocktail()
      Cocktail Sort:
      Also known as Cocktail Shaker Sort or Bidirectional Bubble Sort, is a variation of the Bubble Sort algorithm. It works by repeatedly moving through the list in both directions, comparing adjacent elements and swapping them if they are in the wrong order. This bidirectional movement helps to optimize the sorting process by sorting the largest and smallest elements simultaneously.

      Example:
      1. Start with an unsorted list of elements.
      2. Set two pointers, start and end, initially pointing to the first and last elements of the list, respectively.
      3. Repeat the following steps until no more swaps are made:
        • Move the start pointer from left to right, comparing adjacent elements and swapping them if they are in the wrong order.
        • If any swaps are made during this pass, mark that a swap occurred.
        • Move the end pointer from right to left, comparing adjacent elements and swapping them if they are in the wrong order.
        • If any swaps are made during this pass, mark that a swap occurred.
        • If no swaps occurred during the entire pass (both from start to end and from end to start), the list is already sorted, and the algorithm can terminate.
      4. The sorted list is obtained once the algorithm terminates.
      Note:
      Cocktail Sort differs from the traditional Bubble Sort by introducing the bidirectional movement. This bidirectional traversal helps to improve the efficiency of the algorithm by bringing both the largest and smallest elements closer to their correct positions with each pass.

      Cocktail Sort has a time complexity of O(n^2) in the average and worst cases, where n is the number of elements in the list. Although it has the same time complexity as Bubble Sort, Cocktail Sort tends to perform better in practice due to the bidirectional movement. However, it is still considered relatively inefficient for large datasets.

      Property:
      Worst Case Complexity: O(n^2)
      Best Case Complexity: O(n^2)
      Average Case Complexity: O(n^2)
      Auxiliary Space: O(1)
      Stability: Yes
      See Also:
      • Comb
      • IntroCocktail
      • IntroComb
      • IntroDPQCocktail
      • IntroDPQComb

    • cocktailInc

      protected void cocktailInc(Comparable[] array)
      cocktailInc that implements the cocktail sort algorithm to sort an array of Comparable objects in increasing order.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to unchecked type casting when using the compareTo method. This annotation is not directly related to the functionality of the method but rather a way to handle warnings.
      • The method takes an array of Comparable objects, denoted by array, and performs the cocktail sort algorithm on it.
      • The swapped variable is initially set to true, indicating that there may be swaps to perform in the array.
      • The start variable is set to the index 0, representing the starting point of the current iteration.
      • The end variable is set to the index of the last element in the array, representing the end point of the current iteration.
      • The outer while loop continues as long as there are swaps being made in the array.
      • Inside the while loop, the first for loop iterates from start to (end - 1). It checks pairs of adjacent elements and calls the isSwap method to determine if a swap is necessary. If a swap is made, the swapped variable is set to true.
      • After the first for loop, an if condition checks if any swaps were made in the iteration. If no swaps were made (!swapped), it means the array is already sorted, and the loop breaks.
      • Next, the end index is decremented by 1, as the largest element has already been placed at the correct position in the previous iteration.
      • The second for loop iterates from (end - 1) to start in reverse order. It also checks pairs of adjacent elements and calls the isSwap method to determine if a swap is necessary. If a swap is made, the swapped variable is set to true.
      • After the second for loop, the start index is incremented by 1, as the smallest element has already been placed at the correct position in the previous iteration.
      • The outer while loop continues until no swaps are made in the array, indicating that the array is fully sorted.
      cocktailInc method combines the concepts of bubble sort and selection sort by traversing the array bidirectionally, repeatedly swapping adjacent elements if they are out of order. This process continues until the array becomes fully sorted.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      See Also:
      • SortSwap.isSwapInc(Comparable[], int, int)

    • cocktailInc

      protected void cocktailInc(Comparable[] array, int left, int right)
      cocktailInc that implements the cocktail sort algorithm to sort an array of Comparable objects in increasing order.
      • The method takes an array of Comparable objects, denoted by array, and performs the cocktail sort algorithm on it.
      • The swapped variable is initially set to true, indicating that there may be swaps to perform in the array.
      • The start variable is set to the index 0, representing the starting point of the current iteration.
      • The end variable is set to the index of the last element in the array, representing the end point of the current iteration.
      • The outer while loop continues as long as there are swaps being made in the array.
      • Inside the while loop, the first for loop iterates from start to (end - 1). It checks pairs of adjacent elements and calls the isSwap method to determine if a swap is necessary. If a swap is made, the swapped variable is set to true.
      • After the first for loop, an if condition checks if any swaps were made in the iteration. If no swaps were made (!swapped), it means the array is already sorted, and the loop breaks.
      • Next, the end index is decremented by 1, as the largest element has already been placed at the correct position in the previous iteration.
      • The second for loop iterates from (end - 1) to start in reverse order. It also checks pairs of adjacent elements and calls the isSwap method to determine if a swap is necessary. If a swap is made, the swapped variable is set to true.
      • After the second for loop, the start index is incremented by 1, as the smallest element has already been placed at the correct position in the previous iteration.
      • The outer while loop continues until no swaps are made in the array, indicating that the array is fully sorted.
      cocktailInc method combines the concepts of bubble sort and selection sort by traversing the array bidirectionally, repeatedly swapping adjacent elements if they are out of order. This process continues until the array becomes fully sorted.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - the value in the array must be smaller than a right parameter.
      right - the value in the array must be greater than a left parameter.
      See Also:
      • SortSwap.isSwapInc(Comparable[], int, int)
